Inspired by a true icon! The McLaren F1 is considered one of the most amazing and revolutionary supercars in automotive history. But what are the reasons? 1. Performance: Upon its release in 1992, the McLaren F1 was the fastest production car in the world, with a top speed of 386.4 km/h. 2. Engineering: The F1 was the first production car to use a full carbon fiber monocoque chassis, making it exceptionally light and strong. 3. Central Driving Position: It is a unique three-seater with the driverâ€™s seat centrally positioned, providing optimal visibility and driving experience. And, not to forget: The McLaren F1 is powered by a 6.1-liter BMW V12 engine producing 618 horsepower. This engine was known for its reliability and high-revving capabilities. Only 106 units were ever produced, making it extremely rare and highly sought after by collectors. The combination of groundbreaking technology, exceptional performance, and limited production has made the McLaren F1 a legend in automotive history. #mclarenf1 #v12 #bmwengine #bmw #bmwv12 #bmw #mclaren

Beautiful in blue - the McLaren P1! Unveiled to the public in 2012 at the Paris Motor Show, the P1 was an instant hit. Becoming McLaren's first foray into the hybrid world. It sports a 3.8L Twin Turbo V8, mated to a battery-electric hybrid system dubbed "IPAS" (Integrated Power Assist). Full power output is 903hp and 664lb-ft of torque. That made it the most powerful road McLaren at the time. All that power was then routed to the rear wheels via a Graziano 7-Speed Dual-Clutch transmission. This was good for a 2.8 second 0-60mph and a top speed of 217mph. This particular example is quite well-spec'd. Finished in Lio Blue tinted Carbon Fiber and Black Wheels. On the interior, the theme continues with a two-tone Blue/Black Alcantara trim. In total, 375 examples were made. The entire production run was sold out within a month of going on sale. Today, they are a very sought after car, with value continuing to rise as the years go on. #mclaren #p1 #hypercar #performance #speed #uk ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§ #Anis_Maaouia

My idea for improving performance in F1 circuits' bends. We are used to the idea of suspensions that work with a combination of gas, or oil, and springs, that aim to absorb shocks, thus, ensuring stability, by interfacing tyres between the tarmac and the F1 chassis. But what about using them vertically to connect the various parts of the chassis, not connected to wheels, and horizontally (both length and width), connecting, for example, the front with the mid section and rear, or left to right side of the car? Current F1 cars have smooth wheel suspensions and rigid chassis. If the chassis was made elastic and more responsive to track changes, stability, grip and air penetration would be improved substantially. F1 cars would be able to "twist" their chassis to better adapt to each curve individually. Current F1 suspensions setups work fine in the most crucial bends of the track but not in all of them. By using adaptive chassis suspension, the car could be performant in all of them, especially with the help of a bit of electronics. As for what concerns safety, this could actually be increased, keeping the current chassis robustness and adding a bit of flexibility to absorb the effect of impacts better.
